0: An oil rig is silhouetted against the sunset in St. Lawrence, Texas May 9, 2008. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR PARIS (Reuters) - Oil consumer nations on Thursday announced a surprise release from strategic government petroleum stockpiles in a bid to push down fuel prices and underpin the global economy. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The 28-member International Energy Agency said it would release 60 million barrels a day over an initial 30 days to fill the gap left by the disruption to Libya's output. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The United States will provide half the volumes from its huge 727-million barrel crude reserve, about 1.5 days of U.S. consumption, with Europe supplying 30 pct in crude and refined products and the rest from Pacific OECD nations. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The release, only the third in the IEA's 37-year history, is a blow for the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and in particular for its biggest producer, Saudi Arabia, a close U.S. ally. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Despite Saudi efforts, the producer cartel failed to raise output at a meeting on June 8 leaving Riyadh to pump more unilaterally. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Before the OPEC meeting Riyadh had discussed a crude swap with the United States that would have seen U.S. reserves supplied to Europe, but failed to reach agreement. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The move is significant as it represents a reach by member countries for the remedy of last resort to high prices," said U.S. energy analyst John Kilduff at Again Capital. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Clearly the energy price spike is being cited as the reason for the economic slowdown and this is reaction to that. The Libyan outage provides good cover." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR OPEC member Libya was exporting about 1.2 million bpd before the rebellion that brought its oil industry to a standstill. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "This supply disruption has been underway for some time and its effect has become more pronounced as it has continued," said the IEA. Libya was likely to remain off the market for the rest of 2011, it said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Greater tightness in the oil market threatens to undermine the fragile global economic recovery," the IEA said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR PRICE IMPACT UNCERTAIN NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Oil prices traded $7.07 a barrel lower for benchmark Brent crude at $107.14 and U.S. crude fell $4.68 a barrel to $91.73 a barrel. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR With world oil stocks at comfortably high levels by historical standards, oil analysts were divided on whether prices would fall further or not. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I think the IEA is trying to act like a central bank," said Dominick Chirichella at New York's Energy Management Institute. "I don't think anyone will be comfortable being long oil ... We may see (U.S.) oil trading in the $80s very soon." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR But Carl Larry at Blue Ocean brokerage in New York said prices might not have much further to fall. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "This is an economic stimulus ... in oil dollars," said Larry. "On the other hand I think we have confirmed the bottom of the oil market here at $109 for Brent and $90 for WTI." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR DEPARTURE FOR IEA NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The decision appears to represent a departure for the IEA from previous emergency releases and will not go down well with OPEC. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In the 1990-1991 Gulf conflict when Iraq invaded Kuwait much larger volumes of crude were shut. When Hurricane Katrina in 2005 hit U.S. refineries the IEA release consisted mostly of European refined products to the United States. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "There is no reason to do this," said a senior Gulf Arab OPEC delegate. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The market is not short of supply. Kuwait and the Saudi Arabia have been raising production but there have not been many buyers. The IEA is just playing politics with the U.S." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Leading U.S. oil companies appeared to share that view. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The American Petroleum Institute which represents Exxon and Chevron among others said the plan was "ill timed" and "makes little sense" because there was no supply emergency. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR IEA Executive Director Nobuo Tanaka said the action was intended to work in tandem with Saudi Arabia and other Gulf Arab producers. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Our stocks release is intended to complement the action of those key producers to fill the gap. Together producer and consumers will have taken concrete steps," Tanaka said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The agency will review the need for a further release in a month. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The IEA will continue to watch further developments and we will use the next 30 days to reassess the situation," said Tanaka. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR (additional reporting by Amena Bakr, Alex Lawler, Barbara Lewis, Salem Gebrekidan, Antonita Devotta, Timothy Gardner and Ayesha Rascoe, writing by Richard Mably) action The oil on NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR an world reporting biggest for had IEA's NEWLINE_CHAR 30
